awd_titl_txt: Preparing and Supporting New Earth Science Teachers through a Museum- and School-Based Teacher Residency Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), in partnership with the New York City Department of Education, the New Teacher Center (NTC), and the Center for Education Policy, Applied Research is extending its Masters of Arts in Teaching Residency program with specialization in Secondary Earth Science (AMNH MAT). The only informal science education institution to offer a master's program leading to certification in teaching, the Museum is moving to institutionalize this pioneering approach to the preparation, induction, and retention of STEM teachers. This five-year NSF Teaching Fellows project helps address the documented shortage of Earth science teachers in NYC by supporting a cohort of 15 teacher candidates as they complete a master's degree in education and begin their teaching careers.  The 36-credit, 15-month MAT program, led by a team of education and science faculty, includes two five-month teaching residencies in NYC high-need schools that involve both ELL and special needs rotations. Teaching Fellows receive mentoring, both from residency school teachers and Museum educators. The program also includes a six-week summer residency at the Museum teaching NYC students in the Museum's education programs, and a six-week summer science practicum with Museum scientific staff and postdoctoral fellows. After completing their MAT degree, Teaching Fellows complete four years of teaching in high-need schools, receiving two years of induction support that includes online mentoring through the NTC's e-Mentoring for Student Success (eMSS) and New Teacher Academy sessions at the Museum followed by two years of additional professional development support provided by the Museum's Gottesman Center for Science Teaching and Learning.  AMNH is recruiting Fellows through broad outreach to geoscience majors while also seeking career changers and individuals of diverse backgrounds. In preparing teacher candidates for certification and developing effective teachers, the project is advancing knowledge in the field of STEM teacher preparation and retention. The AMNH MAT model focuses on clinically-rich museum and school-based residency experiences that are central to preparing teachers combined with extensive mentoring during the first two years of teaching, which are critical toward supporting retention efforts. The project also involves opportunities for scientific research, access to scientific collections and halls, and ongoing professional development opportunities after induction. The results provide evidence for assessing and designing programs drawing on the AMNH MAT model and lessons learned from supporting new teachers during their first years of teaching. 

This project presents a new approach to STEM teacher preparation that leverages the unique strengths and resources of an informal  science education (ISE) institution. The project demonstrates the potential of ISEs nationwide to help address the nation's critical need for qualified STEM teachers and to contribute more broadly to reform by strengthening the formal role of science-based cultural institutions in science education. It presents an important model of science and education faculty cooperating in program delivery and for ISE-non-profit teacher preparation and retention partnerships.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the NSF Noyce Teaching Fellows project was to identify, educate, and support the development of 15 new Earth science teachers in the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) Earth Science Residency Program (ESRP). This program was developed to help address the critical shortage of qualified Earth science teachers in New York State and nation-wide. Designed to recruit, prepare, and retain science teachers for high-need secondary schools, this Museum-based program is an innovative, science-rich urban teacher residency.  

In this teacher residency program, residents teach in five high-need secondary schools in New York City and Yonkers serving students in high-poverty areas with diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds. In these schools, preservice teachers learn to teach alongside experienced mentor teachers and specialists in special education and in English as a new language. To support these mentors, the program provides professional learning sessions focused on mentoring, and monthly school-based meetings. This clinically-rich model recognizes that teaching, and the mentoring that comes with experience, are vocations that require and welcome life-long learning. 

To support the retention of its graduates in teaching positions in high-need settings, a two-year New Teacher Induction Program supports beginning teachers as they launch their careers. Throughout the life of the project, a rigorous evaluation process examined central aspects of the program, including teacher retention and the impact of graduates on the academic outcomes of students and on the schools in which they work. Evaluation of the program has been a standard since its inception, and findings indicate that the AMNH MAT residency program has been successful in preparing Earth science teachers to teach in high-need schools and to have positive impacts on students and mentors in partnership schools. To date, the AMNH MAT Earth Science Residency Program has prepared 152 certified Earth Science teachers to teach in high-need middle schools and high schools. Some of the graduates prepared under this award have become teachers in the program's partner schools, and have taken on the role of mentors for AMNH ESRP preservice teachers.

Supported with additional Noyce funds from this award, the Culturally Responsive Education Professional Learning Group (CRE PLG) began its work together in the fall of 2018, immediately following their two-year induction period. The CRE PLG is an AMNH MAT ESRP project through which Noyce Fellows engage in reviewing the literature, conduct lesson study and collaborative teacher research, and develop and facilitate professional learning workshops. This work is designed for Noyce Fellows to explore and enact fundamental tenets of culturally responsive and sustaining education, including holding high expectations for all students' academic learning, drawing connections to students' cultures, valuing students' assets and using them as resources for teaching and learning, and supporting students in developing a critical stance toward sociopolitical structures and processes (Wallace, Howes, et al., 2022). ln addition to integrating and studying CRE in their science classrooms, many members of the group have taken on a leadership role within their schools and have shared the work of the CRE PLG with their colleagues and administration. The CRE PLG has frequently developed and facilitated teacher professional learning focused on culturally responsive and sustaining science education for program residents, graduates, mentors, and more broadly at the Museum for New York City inservice teachers and at national conferences.

A primary outcome of the work on this project is a book contract with a publisher. This collaboratively written volume will focus on the CRE PLG's teacher research into culturally responsive science teaching in their classrooms. An important contribution to the field of science education, this book 1) attends to the need for teachers to learn about, implement, and research culturally responsive and sustaining education in science classrooms, and 2) is written by teachers for teachers, filling a need to bring culturally responsive and sustaining instruction into secondary science with stories and strategies for what culturally responsive and sustaining education can "look like" in science classrooms.

Another achievement that grew from the work supported by this award was a successful proposal for a Noyce Track 4 research grant. The work with the CRE PLG served as inspiration for designing a cross-institutional qualitative study to explore culturally responsive science teaching with two other Noyce partner programs. This award supports an exploration of how teacher education programs, and the teachers they prepare, envision and implement culturally responsive and sustaining science teaching instruction in high-need schools. 


 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Elaine Howes
